name: 歐洲地理文化的幻象與相遇
restrict: ◎第一階段限 歐洲文化學程
description: This course explores various manners in which the Europeans have historically imagined and conceptualized otherness. With a focus on such aspects as ‘wonder,’ ‘otherness’ or ‘Orientalism,’ this course takes students from classical Greece to contemporary times and discusses both unbridled fascination (sinophilia) and radical rejection (racial theories) in Europeans’ perceptions about themselves and others.
goals: explores various manners in which the Europeans have historically imagined and conceptualized otherness
syllabus:
1.    Introduction: unicorns and Orientalism

2.    The Others of classical times: Greek vs. Barbarian, Hyperboreans, Scythians; the world of Pliny

3.    The imaginary world of Alexander the Great

4.    Conceptualizing ‘wonder’

5.    Monsters, Jews, Saracens: medieval projections

6.    The exotic other: Prester John; Sir John Mandeville; Cathay and the way thither

7.    Learning about the world: the story of maps

8.    Chronicling the Other: Columbus and his journals

9.    Classification and accommodation in the 16th and 17th centuries

10\. The ‘near’ otherness: The Turk

11\. The wise Chinese

12\. The noble savage

13\. Other Enlightenment matters: new paradigms of otherness

14\. Inventing the near Other: Eastern Europe

15\. The cult of nations: representation, racism, discrimination

16\. Orientalism, empire and narrative

17\. Stereotyping the Other in popular culture.

Problems today
